THE NEWS :',ETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 17.
HOPKINS WINS SECOND PLACE
Speedy University of Virginia Athletes
Roll Up More Points Than Black
and Blue in the George
Washington Meet.

Although expecting to bring
home the banner for first place, the
Hopkins track team has every
reason to feel proud pf its good
work in the annual indoor meet
of the George Washington University. Horrax won first place in
the 50-yard hurdles, and second
in the high jump. Dingan won the
12-pound shot-put, and made a new
South Atlantic record for this
event bY putting the leaden pellet
49 feet to inches. Lee and Reeside
were second in the mile and halfmile, respectively, This made a
total of nineteen points, while the
Virginians, who won the meet,
rolled up thirty-four points.
Captain Fulton and ex-Captain
Stollenwerck were greatly missed
in the quarter and in the half, and
with these two runners in good condition Hopkins would have won the
-meet. Ray, Dodson, Brown, Zinn,
and Catlin showed up well in their
events, but were not quite fast
enough to place. They all•showed
that they had the makings .of good
runners in them, and are certain to
.be heard from in some of the other
meets, before the winter is over.
All the rooters who accompanied
the Black and Blue team to Washington were thrilled by the strong
finish of Lee in the mile. He
gradually caught up with and
passed most of the contestants who
had received large handicaps, and
he worked hard to overtake Boyle
who had a 40-yard start on him.
Boyle kept the lead and finished a
few yards ahead of Lee, but if the
race had been one lap more the
result would almost certainly have
been different.
Horrax is, without doubt, the star
athlete of the Hopkins track team.
In every meet last year he came
away with one or more medals in
spite of being put at scratch in,,
nearly all the events he was entered'
in. His versatility is wonderful.
He is a crack hurdler, pole vaulter,
high jumper, broad jumper, and
hop-step-and-jump artist. He demonstrated his sterling ability again
last Saturday and showed he is as
good, if not better, than last year.
He is expected to figure prominently in the joint games to be
held by Hopkins and the Fifth
Regiment Athletic Association this
Saturday night at the Fifth Regiment Armory. Reserved seats will
be put on sale at Albaugh's today,
and all prospective purchasers are
advised to buy early before the
choice seats are all sold.'

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 6, 1911.

MUSICAL CLUB WINS LAURELS

HARESFOOT REHEARSALS BEGIN

Concert Given Before a Large Audi- 1 The Play Is to Be Rewritten and Localized at Hopkins—Only One Baldence—A Splendid Programme
more Production to Be Given.
Is Given.

The most successful concert,
given so far by the Musical Club,
was held last Thursday evening at
the parish house of the Church of
St. Michael and All Angles. The
hall was packed with a large and
enthusiastic audience.
The programme:
Glee Club:
"The University Ode,"
"Mynheer Vandunck,"
"Johnny Hopkins,"
"Oh, Who Will O'er the Downs,"
"Tom, Tom, The Piper's Son,"
and
"Rah! For the Black and Blue."
Instrumental Club:
"Every Little Movement,"
•
"Havana,"
"Cavalleria Rusticana,"
"My Hero,"
"Meet Me Tonight in Dreamland," and
"Molly Lee."
Violin solo:
Mr. Ray.
Quartette:
Solos by Mr. Uhlig and Mr.
Ruth.
"Toni, Tom, The Piper's Son,"
and "Molly Lee" won great applause, as did Mr. Ruth's solo, and
Mr. Stollenwerck's medley.
Those taking part in the concert
were: J. K. Uhlig, H. B. Dornblazer, 0. K. Schmied, S. D. White,
E. D. Martin, G. M. Gillet, F. K.
Leland, J. H. Marston, Jr., H. M.
Coblentz, E. C. Stollenwerck, W.
0: Weyforth,. Jr., L. L. Jacobs, L.
T. Breuninger, L. W. Perce, T.
DeC. Ruth, H. B. Hering, B. Tappan, H. H. Lloyd, W. Ray, W. F.
Geissel, H. M. Wagner, Jr., C. J.
Weber, S. S. Merrick, A. R. Gminder, and R. Fl. Jenkins.
Since the class of 1911 at
Chicago passed the decree that
every male student must raise a
mustache before June or be ducked
in the pool, a furious competition
has commenced. The undergraduate newspaper has announced that
to the senior that first produces
"twenty-four bona fide hairs" on
each side of his upper lip, will be
awarded a bound volume of the
Daily Haroon as a prize.
Harvard University has devised
a new degree, that of "Associate
in Arts," which will be given to
students who complete the course
in the new department of university
extension.

The Haresfoot .Club rehearsals
for the show to be given this spring
will start this week. There has
been some delay in getting the
books, but they have now been
received from the publisher, and
work on the production begins in
earnest.
The play selected this year is
Geo. H. Broadhurst's farce, "What
Happened to Jones," which is being
partly rewritten, the scene localized
at Hopkins, and a couple of songs
and dances introduced. In view of
these changes in the farce the club
has decided that a change of name
is not only justified, but desirable,
and in order to have a large number
of good titles from which to make
a selection, they are offering a box
as a prize to the one making the
suggestion of the name they choose.
The name should be short, suggestive, and clever, and everyone—
in the University and out, from
King George V to Walter Noir—
is invited to send suggestions.
The club is arranging a trip to
take place during the Easter holidays; and while several invitations
have been received and other places
communicated with, the route has
not been definitely fixed as yet.
There is to be but one Baltimore
production—at Albaugh's, Thursday night, April 28th, for the benefit of the Homewood Fund. This
will give the students an opportunity to help in a cause that is
near and dear to the hearts of all
Hopkins men.
The parts have not been kfinitely
decided upon—nor will they be till
all the material has been tried out
and .the best possible cast picked.
The play is screamingly funny, and
with so much experienced talent
in the club, backed by promising
new men, and under the coaching
of Henry Edward Warner, who
produced "The Magistrate" two
years ago, the club ought to score
a very great hit.
Among those out "for the parts
are: Lee, Herring, McCabe, Frederick, Fulton, Murray, Ellicott, Bond,
Martin, Carter, Cole, Tappan,
Marsten, Hulbert, Stockett, Martine, Belt, Price, Rogers, Randolph,
Buckleri Ober,Marshall,and Dorsey.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
BOBBITT WINS CONTEST
The Judges Decide Unanimously in His
Favor—All Contestants Make
Splendid Speeches.

A meeting of the Arbitration
Society was held on Wednesday,
February 1st, for the purpose of
holding trials to choose the speakers
to represent Hopkins at the oratorical contest to be held later in the
year. Several colleges of Maryland are to send representatives
who will speak in contest on some
phase of international arbitration.
A preliminary contest was therefore held in the assembly room of
McCoy Hall, with Dr. Kirby F.
Smith, Dr. French, and Mr. Ball
as judges.
Mr. R. E. Miller, chairman of
the Committee on Arrangements,
introduced the speakers, of whom
there were three: Messrs. Charles
L. Getz, Lindsay Rogers, and L. B.
Bobbitt.
Mr. Getz spoke first, on "Compulsory Internatiotial Arbitration."
Mr. Rogers spoke on the subject,
"A Nation's Greatness."
Mr. Bobbitt chose for his remarks, "Patriotism and Peace." He
pointed out that war does not settle
the justice of the cause at issue
between two nations, and that the
money spent in times of peace could
more advantageously be spent on
economic improvements.
In announcing the decision of the
judges, Dr. Smith said that he and
his associates were particularly
pleased with the work done by the
contestants, and that he wished that
there had been more men participating.
The decision rendered was unanimously in favor of Mr. Bobbitt,
who had won on the general excellence of his speech, and of his
delivery.
Mr. Bobbitt will, therefore, represent Johns Hopkins in the Maryland contest, which will take place
on March 16.
This contest is to be conducted
under the direction of the Intercollegiate Peace Association; and the
prizes are offered by the Maryland
Peace Association. Seventy-five dollars has been offered as the first
prize, and fifty dollars a,s the second.
Already St. John's, Georgetown,
and Washington Colleges have entered, while several more are expected to take part. The Johns

PENNSYLVANIA RELAY RACES

FOOTBALL PROSPECTS BRIGHT

The Date of the Meet Has Been
Announced—Splendid Prizes
to be Given.

Big Games Scheduled For New Year—
The Teams Strength Will Be
Taxed to The Utmost.

The date of the relay races and
track meet at the University of
Pennsylvania has been announced
to be Saturday, April 29. The program is very much the same that
it has been for past years. There
are to be three relay races for four.
man teams for distances of one
mile,two miles, and four miles. The
classification of Hopkins for these
races is the same as for last year,
our team being placed in the sixth
group along with Haverford, Fordham, Western Maryland, Bucknell,
Ohio Wesleyan, New York University, and University of North
Carolina. This year we have a
better chance than ever before to
show whether we belong in this
group or higher, and it is to be
hoped that next year we will be
found in the class with Carlisle,
Swarthmore, and others.
The prizes to be awarded are as
follows:
A silk banner to the winning
team, and to each member of the
team a gold watch; when four
teams contest, a silver cup will be
given to each member of the team
finishing second; when six teams
contest, cups will be given as third
prizes. In addition, there will be
a number of other individual events
in which the first prizes will be
gold watches. The prizes are indeed very liberal and it is expected
that over two hundred teams will
be attracted to the meet.

Gradually through long years of
hard work the football team has
worked itself up into a position
where it is able to demand recognition from stronger teams than
those of the Maryland colleges. It
now remains to be seen whether we
are worthy of the position and if
we can hold it. This is what-Captain Jack Fulton will attempt to do
next year; and if he has the support and the material which was
available last year he will succeed.
The schedule for 1911 is the
hardest by far that any Hopkins
team has ever had. Although the
schedule is not yet completed, it
has in it already the names of
several big colleges, such as the
Navy and University of Virginia.
The Navy game will be the first
game of the season, October 7, at
Annapolis. Accordingly, the team
will have to round into shape before the season starts instead of
postponing practice until the week
before the first game, as heretofore.
The second, also, will be played
away from home,Stevens Institute,
at Hoboken, on October 14. The
other two games that have been
settled are with the University
of Virginia, on November i r, and
with the Western Maryland College, at ,Hornewood, on Thanksgiving Day. The date of the'game
with Carlisle has not yet been fixed.
Coach Lynn will be back again
next year, and he will be able to
get a good many of the medical
men out. The assistant coach is
uncertain, but Sieber will probably
be on the job again. Altogether
the prospects for the 1911 football team are such as never were
before and the stands at Homewood ought to be taxed to their
full capacity at every game.

Senior

Class Meeting.

At a meeting of the senior class,
last Thursday, several important
matters were brought up. Ben
Tappan, chairman of the banquet
committee, announced that the date
of the senior banquet had been
fixed for February 21. The banquet is to be held at the New
Howard Hotel, at seven o'clock.
The Senior Prom. Committee announced the date for June 12. This
dance will be open to every one
in the University. The subscription will be $3.00. It will be held
on a large scale and will surpass
anything of the kind ever held at
the University.
The Hullabaloo Board reported
that the progress on the book was
advancing very rapidly, and that
it would be an ideal year-book.
The finances were also reported to
be in a better condition than was
at first supposed, since all the advertisements secured last year were
found to be valid.

6, 1911

The baseball squad has grown so
large that, owing to the limited
amount of space in the "cage,"
Coach Hooper and Captain Pieper
have been forced to weed out some
of the candidates. Out of the forty
or more candidates, Coach Hooper
picked the eighteen who have done
the most promising work so far,
and he will work with these until
the team gets out of doors. As
soon as the outdoor practice begins
all the candidates will be asked to
join the squad again, as Manager
Sattler intends to arrange a schedule for one or more strong scrub
teams. The eighteen players who
will practice in the "cage"
are: Peiper Sattler, Howel, Rice,
Holmes, Fulton,Campbell, McCabe,
Hardy, Sutton, Russell, Wolfe, Disney, Stewart, Dorsey, Hanzsche,
Meekins, and Carroll. 'Manager
Sattler announced that the home
games would be played at Homewood. This is good news for the
backers of the baseball team. At
the beginning of this year the problem of securing grounds threatened
to be a serious one. It did not seem
likely that the Homewood committee would consent to the laying
off of a diamond on the Homewood field, especially as it will be
used so much by the lacrosse team.
Such interest was shown in baseball and the fact that no other enclosed grounds were obtainable that
the Homewood committee finally
gave its consent. The big games,
like those with Harvard and the
University of Pennsylvania, should
draw large crowds, and this fact,
coupled with the Homewood enclosed grounds, should enable the
nine to have a very successful
season financially. The old Country
School grounds, which are part of
the Homewood estate, will be used
for the daily practice as soon as
the squad is able to begin outdoors.
The season will probably start
on April 1st, with Eastern College,
although that game has not yet
been definitely determined upon.
From that date on, there will be a
game every Saturday until the end
of May, with the single exception
of May 6; and Manager Sattler
hopes to arrange a game with
Lehigh for that date.

reproduction of the Black Letter
Edition of 1611 of the Bible.

government to the universities of

I.—American Journal of Mathematics.

Saturday afternoon there was
played in the trophy room a chess
match between the City College
Chess Team and the best players
in the minor tournament here.
Ober and Rosenfeld, of Hopkins,
won their games; Hammond lost
his; and the game between Brown
and Kuehn was left unfinished
to be played off Monday afternoon.
Ober easily defeated his opponent,
requiring only thirteen moves to
checkmate him. The game between
Perlman and Rosenfeld was a long,
drawn-out affair of some fifty
moves, during which both players
missed several opportunities to
'mate. The Hammond-Melamet
game was by far the most interesting, and the best played. The
game continued fairly even for
about fifteen moves. Then Melamet began getting a somewhat
stronger position. Soon, however,
Hammond thought he saw an opportunity for a quick checkmate
and sacrificed a rook to accomplish his purpose. But he had miscalculated the results of the move
and, handicapped by the loss of
his rook, he was forced to resign
the game to Melamet on the twentyfifth move.
Kuehn had somewhat the advantage of Brown when the latter
had to leave to catch the train to
Washington to participate in the
George Washington games. If
Brown loses, the match will result
in a tie, and will probably be played
over. The match was refereed by
W. E. Pearce, captain of the Varsity chess team.
Only one game remains to be
played in the major tournament—
Benedict and Melamet. Last week
Starck lost to Pearce.
Recently there was another reminder, in the shape of a fire in
one of the offices of the Geological
Survey in Washington, of the
necessity of protecting valuable
records, books, and manuscripts
against the flames. Two years ago
Prof. C. M. Andrews wrote an interesting article for THE NEwsLETTER entitled "Tragedies in
.\lanuscripts." He also emphasized the need of protection in this
respect. It is just as necessary to
preserve the records of scholarly
labors as those of business transactions.

THE NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 6, 1911
DEBATE QUESTION CHOSEN
The Dates of The Triangular League
And Interclass Debates Have
Been Settled.

Mr. Donald K. Belt, manager
of the 'varsity debating team, announces the date of the Triangular
League debate to be April 28. The
colleges to debate on that evening
will be Washington and Lee, Gettysi)urg, and Johns Hopkins. We
.1 send one team to Gettysburg,
the second will stay at home
to debate Washington and Lee. It
is unfortunate that the Haresfoot
Club has scheduled a date in the
city for the same night, and it is
to be hoped that it will be possible
for them to fix another date. It
would be a difficult matter to
change the date of the debate, as
that was decided only after a long
correspondence between the three
colleges.
The committee on the question
consists of . G. D. Hancock, of
Washington and Lee; C. F. Sanders, of Pennsylvania; and Dr. J.
C. French, of Hopkins has adopted
the following subject:
Resolved, That the public welfare would be promoted by a readjustment of the power of the
Federal and State governments in
pursuance of a general policy of
centralization.
The subject is interesting and
One which is provoking much discussion at the present time, and a
large number of candidates should
present themselves for the team.
The same subject will be debated
by the juniors and seniors in the
interclass debate on March 24.

THE NEWS :',ETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 17.
HOPKINS WINS SECOND PLACE
Speedy University of Virginia Athletes
Roll Up More Points Than Black
and Blue in the George
Washington Meet.

Although expecting to bring
home the banner for first place, the
Hopkins track team has every
reason to feel proud pf its good
work in the annual indoor meet
of the George Washington University. Horrax won first place in
the 50-yard hurdles, and second
in the high jump. Dingan won the
12-pound shot-put, and made a new
South Atlantic record for this
event bY putting the leaden pellet
49 feet to inches. Lee and Reeside
were second in the mile and halfmile, respectively, This made a
total of nineteen points, while the
Virginians, who won the meet,
rolled up thirty-four points.
Captain Fulton and ex-Captain
Stollenwerck were greatly missed
in the quarter and in the half, and
with these two runners in good condition Hopkins would have won the
-meet. Ray, Dodson, Brown, Zinn,
and Catlin showed up well in their
events, but were not quite fast
enough to place. They all•showed
that they had the makings .of good
runners in them, and are certain to
.be heard from in some of the other
meets, before the winter is over.
All the rooters who accompanied
the Black and Blue team to Washington were thrilled by the strong
finish of Lee in the mile. He
gradually caught up with and
passed most of the contestants who
had received large handicaps, and
he worked hard to overtake Boyle
who had a 40-yard start on him.
Boyle kept the lead and finished a
few yards ahead of Lee, but if the
race had been one lap more the
result would almost certainly have
been different.
Horrax is, without doubt, the star
athlete of the Hopkins track team.
In every meet last year he came
away with one or more medals in
spite of being put at scratch in,,
nearly all the events he was entered'
in. His versatility is wonderful.
He is a crack hurdler, pole vaulter,
high jumper, broad jumper, and
hop-step-and-jump artist. He demonstrated his sterling ability again
last Saturday and showed he is as
good, if not better, than last year.
He is expected to figure prominently in the joint games to be
held by Hopkins and the Fifth
Regiment Athletic Association this
Saturday night at the Fifth Regiment Armory. Reserved seats will
be put on sale at Albaugh's today,
and all prospective purchasers are
advised to buy early before the
choice seats are all sold.'

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 6, 1911.

MUSICAL CLUB WINS LAURELS

HARESFOOT REHEARSALS BEGIN

Concert Given Before a Large Audi- 1 The Play Is to Be Rewritten and Localized at Hopkins—Only One Baldence—A Splendid Programme
more Production to Be Given.
Is Given.

The most successful concert,
given so far by the Musical Club,
was held last Thursday evening at
the parish house of the Church of
St. Michael and All Angles. The
hall was packed with a large and
enthusiastic audience.
The programme:
Glee Club:
"The University Ode,"
"Mynheer Vandunck,"
"Johnny Hopkins,"
"Oh, Who Will O'er the Downs,"
"Tom, Tom, The Piper's Son,"
and
"Rah! For the Black and Blue."
Instrumental Club:
"Every Little Movement,"
•
"Havana,"
"Cavalleria Rusticana,"
"My Hero,"
"Meet Me Tonight in Dreamland," and
"Molly Lee."
Violin solo:
Mr. Ray.
Quartette:
Solos by Mr. Uhlig and Mr.
Ruth.
"Toni, Tom, The Piper's Son,"
and "Molly Lee" won great applause, as did Mr. Ruth's solo, and
Mr. Stollenwerck's medley.
Those taking part in the concert
were: J. K. Uhlig, H. B. Dornblazer, 0. K. Schmied, S. D. White,
E. D. Martin, G. M. Gillet, F. K.
Leland, J. H. Marston, Jr., H. M.
Coblentz, E. C. Stollenwerck, W.
0: Weyforth,. Jr., L. L. Jacobs, L.
T. Breuninger, L. W. Perce, T.
DeC. Ruth, H. B. Hering, B. Tappan, H. H. Lloyd, W. Ray, W. F.
Geissel, H. M. Wagner, Jr., C. J.
Weber, S. S. Merrick, A. R. Gminder, and R. Fl. Jenkins.
Since the class of 1911 at
Chicago passed the decree that
every male student must raise a
mustache before June or be ducked
in the pool, a furious competition
has commenced. The undergraduate newspaper has announced that
to the senior that first produces
"twenty-four bona fide hairs" on
each side of his upper lip, will be
awarded a bound volume of the
Daily Haroon as a prize.
Harvard University has devised
a new degree, that of "Associate
in Arts," which will be given to
students who complete the course
in the new department of university
extension.

The Haresfoot .Club rehearsals
for the show to be given this spring
will start this week. There has
been some delay in getting the
books, but they have now been
received from the publisher, and
work on the production begins in
earnest.
The play selected this year is
Geo. H. Broadhurst's farce, "What
Happened to Jones," which is being
partly rewritten, the scene localized
at Hopkins, and a couple of songs
and dances introduced. In view of
these changes in the farce the club
has decided that a change of name
is not only justified, but desirable,
and in order to have a large number
of good titles from which to make
a selection, they are offering a box
as a prize to the one making the
suggestion of the name they choose.
The name should be short, suggestive, and clever, and everyone—
in the University and out, from
King George V to Walter Noir—
is invited to send suggestions.
The club is arranging a trip to
take place during the Easter holidays; and while several invitations
have been received and other places
communicated with, the route has
not been definitely fixed as yet.
There is to be but one Baltimore
production—at Albaugh's, Thursday night, April 28th, for the benefit of the Homewood Fund. This
will give the students an opportunity to help in a cause that is
near and dear to the hearts of all
Hopkins men.
The parts have not been kfinitely
decided upon—nor will they be till
all the material has been tried out
and .the best possible cast picked.
The play is screamingly funny, and
with so much experienced talent
in the club, backed by promising
new men, and under the coaching
of Henry Edward Warner, who
produced "The Magistrate" two
years ago, the club ought to score
a very great hit.
Among those out "for the parts
are: Lee, Herring, McCabe, Frederick, Fulton, Murray, Ellicott, Bond,
Martin, Carter, Cole, Tappan,
Marsten, Hulbert, Stockett, Martine, Belt, Price, Rogers, Randolph,
Buckleri Ober,Marshall,and Dorsey.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
BOBBITT WINS CONTEST
The Judges Decide Unanimously in His
Favor—All Contestants Make
Splendid Speeches.

A meeting of the Arbitration
Society was held on Wednesday,
February 1st, for the purpose of
holding trials to choose the speakers
to represent Hopkins at the oratorical contest to be held later in the
year. Several colleges of Maryland are to send representatives
who will speak in contest on some
phase of international arbitration.
A preliminary contest was therefore held in the assembly room of
McCoy Hall, with Dr. Kirby F.
Smith, Dr. French, and Mr. Ball
as judges.
Mr. R. E. Miller, chairman of
the Committee on Arrangements,
introduced the speakers, of whom
there were three: Messrs. Charles
L. Getz, Lindsay Rogers, and L. B.
Bobbitt.
Mr. Getz spoke first, on "Compulsory Internatiotial Arbitration."
Mr. Rogers spoke on the subject,
"A Nation's Greatness."
Mr. Bobbitt chose for his remarks, "Patriotism and Peace." He
pointed out that war does not settle
the justice of the cause at issue
between two nations, and that the
money spent in times of peace could
more advantageously be spent on
economic improvements.
In announcing the decision of the
judges, Dr. Smith said that he and
his associates were particularly
pleased with the work done by the
contestants, and that he wished that
there had been more men participating.
The decision rendered was unanimously in favor of Mr. Bobbitt,
who had won on the general excellence of his speech, and of his
delivery.
Mr. Bobbitt will, therefore, represent Johns Hopkins in the Maryland contest, which will take place
on March 16.
This contest is to be conducted
under the direction of the Intercollegiate Peace Association; and the
prizes are offered by the Maryland
Peace Association. Seventy-five dollars has been offered as the first
prize, and fifty dollars a,s the second.
Already St. John's, Georgetown,
and Washington Colleges have entered, while several more are expected to take part. The Johns

PENNSYLVANIA RELAY RACES

FOOTBALL PROSPECTS BRIGHT

The Date of the Meet Has Been
Announced—Splendid Prizes
to be Given.

Big Games Scheduled For New Year—
The Teams Strength Will Be
Taxed to The Utmost.

The date of the relay races and
track meet at the University of
Pennsylvania has been announced
to be Saturday, April 29. The program is very much the same that
it has been for past years. There
are to be three relay races for four.
man teams for distances of one
mile,two miles, and four miles. The
classification of Hopkins for these
races is the same as for last year,
our team being placed in the sixth
group along with Haverford, Fordham, Western Maryland, Bucknell,
Ohio Wesleyan, New York University, and University of North
Carolina. This year we have a
better chance than ever before to
show whether we belong in this
group or higher, and it is to be
hoped that next year we will be
found in the class with Carlisle,
Swarthmore, and others.
The prizes to be awarded are as
follows:
A silk banner to the winning
team, and to each member of the
team a gold watch; when four
teams contest, a silver cup will be
given to each member of the team
finishing second; when six teams
contest, cups will be given as third
prizes. In addition, there will be
a number of other individual events
in which the first prizes will be
gold watches. The prizes are indeed very liberal and it is expected
that over two hundred teams will
be attracted to the meet.

Gradually through long years of
hard work the football team has
worked itself up into a position
where it is able to demand recognition from stronger teams than
those of the Maryland colleges. It
now remains to be seen whether we
are worthy of the position and if
we can hold it. This is what-Captain Jack Fulton will attempt to do
next year; and if he has the support and the material which was
available last year he will succeed.
The schedule for 1911 is the
hardest by far that any Hopkins
team has ever had. Although the
schedule is not yet completed, it
has in it already the names of
several big colleges, such as the
Navy and University of Virginia.
The Navy game will be the first
game of the season, October 7, at
Annapolis. Accordingly, the team
will have to round into shape before the season starts instead of
postponing practice until the week
before the first game, as heretofore.
The second, also, will be played
away from home,Stevens Institute,
at Hoboken, on October 14. The
other two games that have been
settled are with the University
of Virginia, on November i r, and
with the Western Maryland College, at ,Hornewood, on Thanksgiving Day. The date of the'game
with Carlisle has not yet been fixed.
Coach Lynn will be back again
next year, and he will be able to
get a good many of the medical
men out. The assistant coach is
uncertain, but Sieber will probably
be on the job again. Altogether
the prospects for the 1911 football team are such as never were
before and the stands at Homewood ought to be taxed to their
full capacity at every game.

Senior

Class Meeting.

At a meeting of the senior class,
last Thursday, several important
matters were brought up. Ben
Tappan, chairman of the banquet
committee, announced that the date
of the senior banquet had been
fixed for February 21. The banquet is to be held at the New
Howard Hotel, at seven o'clock.
The Senior Prom. Committee announced the date for June 12. This
dance will be open to every one
in the University. The subscription will be $3.00. It will be held
on a large scale and will surpass
anything of the kind ever held at
the University.
The Hullabaloo Board reported
that the progress on the book was
advancing very rapidly, and that
it would be an ideal year-book.
The finances were also reported to
be in a better condition than was
at first supposed, since all the advertisements secured last year were
found to be valid.

6, 1911

The baseball squad has grown so
large that, owing to the limited
amount of space in the "cage,"
Coach Hooper and Captain Pieper
have been forced to weed out some
of the candidates. Out of the forty
or more candidates, Coach Hooper
picked the eighteen who have done
the most promising work so far,
and he will work with these until
the team gets out of doors. As
soon as the outdoor practice begins
all the candidates will be asked to
join the squad again, as Manager
Sattler intends to arrange a schedule for one or more strong scrub
teams. The eighteen players who
will practice in the "cage"
are: Peiper Sattler, Howel, Rice,
Holmes, Fulton,Campbell, McCabe,
Hardy, Sutton, Russell, Wolfe, Disney, Stewart, Dorsey, Hanzsche,
Meekins, and Carroll. 'Manager
Sattler announced that the home
games would be played at Homewood. This is good news for the
backers of the baseball team. At
the beginning of this year the problem of securing grounds threatened
to be a serious one. It did not seem
likely that the Homewood committee would consent to the laying
off of a diamond on the Homewood field, especially as it will be
used so much by the lacrosse team.
Such interest was shown in baseball and the fact that no other enclosed grounds were obtainable that
the Homewood committee finally
gave its consent. The big games,
like those with Harvard and the
University of Pennsylvania, should
draw large crowds, and this fact,
coupled with the Homewood enclosed grounds, should enable the
nine to have a very successful
season financially. The old Country
School grounds, which are part of
the Homewood estate, will be used
for the daily practice as soon as
the squad is able to begin outdoors.
The season will probably start
on April 1st, with Eastern College,
although that game has not yet
been definitely determined upon.
From that date on, there will be a
game every Saturday until the end
of May, with the single exception
of May 6; and Manager Sattler
hopes to arrange a game with
Lehigh for that date.

the book-binders' art, in addition
to the practical work.

will shortly issue a photographic
reproduction of the Black Letter
Edition of 1611 of the Bible.

government to the universities of

Johns Hopkins Press
I.—American Journal of Mathematics.

Saturday afternoon there was
played in the trophy room a chess
match between the City College
Chess Team and the best players
in the minor tournament here.
Ober and Rosenfeld, of Hopkins,
won their games; Hammond lost
his; and the game between Brown
and Kuehn was left unfinished
to be played off Monday afternoon.
Ober easily defeated his opponent,
requiring only thirteen moves to
checkmate him. The game between
Perlman and Rosenfeld was a long,
drawn-out affair of some fifty
moves, during which both players
missed several opportunities to
'mate. The Hammond-Melamet
game was by far the most interesting, and the best played. The
game continued fairly even for
about fifteen moves. Then Melamet began getting a somewhat
stronger position. Soon, however,
Hammond thought he saw an opportunity for a quick checkmate
and sacrificed a rook to accomplish his purpose. But he had miscalculated the results of the move
and, handicapped by the loss of
his rook, he was forced to resign
the game to Melamet on the twentyfifth move.
Kuehn had somewhat the advantage of Brown when the latter
had to leave to catch the train to
Washington to participate in the
George Washington games. If
Brown loses, the match will result
in a tie, and will probably be played
over. The match was refereed by
W. E. Pearce, captain of the Varsity chess team.
Only one game remains to be
played in the major tournament—
Benedict and Melamet. Last week
Starck lost to Pearce.
Recently there was another reminder, in the shape of a fire in
one of the offices of the Geological
Survey in Washington, of the
necessity of protecting valuable
records, books, and manuscripts
against the flames. Two years ago
Prof. C. M. Andrews wrote an interesting article for THE NEwsLETTER entitled "Tragedies in
.\lanuscripts." He also emphasized the need of protection in this
respect. It is just as necessary to
preserve the records of scholarly
labors as those of business transactions.

THE NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 6, 1911
DEBATE QUESTION CHOSEN
The Dates of The Triangular League
And Interclass Debates Have
Been Settled.

Mr. Donald K. Belt, manager
of the 'varsity debating team, announces the date of the Triangular
League debate to be April 28. The
colleges to debate on that evening
will be Washington and Lee, Gettysi)urg, and Johns Hopkins. We
.1 send one team to Gettysburg,
the second will stay at home
to debate Washington and Lee. It
is unfortunate that the Haresfoot
Club has scheduled a date in the
city for the same night, and it is
to be hoped that it will be possible
for them to fix another date. It
would be a difficult matter to
change the date of the debate, as
that was decided only after a long
correspondence between the three
colleges.
The committee on the question
consists of . G. D. Hancock, of
Washington and Lee; C. F. Sanders, of Pennsylvania; and Dr. J.
C. French, of Hopkins has adopted
the following subject:
Resolved, That the public welfare would be promoted by a readjustment of the power of the
Federal and State governments in
pursuance of a general policy of
centralization.
The subject is interesting and
One which is provoking much discussion at the present time, and a
large number of candidates should
present themselves for the team.
The same subject will be debated
by the juniors and seniors in the
interclass debate on March 24.

Last summer Allan F. Westcott,
instructor in English in Columbia
University, discovered in the British Museum a manuscript containing more than sixty poems by
James I, King of England, not
half of which have yet been printed.
Mr. Westcott expects to publish
the manuscript with notes and an
introduction.
